skill.name: Angular 20 Standalone Component
skill.description: Create Angular 20 standalone components using modern patterns: Signals for state management, input()/output() functions (not decorators), @if/@for/@switch control flow (not *ngIf/*ngFor), inject() dependency injection (not constructor), and OnPush change detection. Use this skill when scaffolding new UI components that need reactive state, form handling, or integration with services following the three-layer architecture.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and TypeScript code examples for Angular 20 component patterns. No executable scripts, network calls, file system access, or code execution capabilities. Contains only instructional content describing Angular best practices.

content.value_statement: Angular 20 introduces major syntax changes that improve performance and developer experience. This skill helps developers scaffold production-ready standalone components using Signals, new input/output functions, and modern control flow syntax.
actual_capabilities: Scaffold standalone Angular 20 components with modern syntax
Implement reactive state management using signal(), computed(), and effect()
Use input() and output() functions instead of decorators
Configure OnPush change detection for optimal performance
Integrate services using inject() instead of constructor injection
limitations: Does not generate full project structure or configuration files
Does not create service or repository layer implementations
Does not validate existing code against Angular 20 patterns
Does not provide testing scaffolding or test examples

output_examples.input: Create an Angular 20 standalone component for displaying a product list with loading state
output: ✓ Uses signal() for products, loading, and error state
✓ Uses computed() for hasProducts derived state

best_practices: Use signal() for all component state and expose via asReadonly() for immutable access
Always use OnPush change detection with standalone components for performance
Inject services using inject() function instead of constructor for cleaner code
Separate concerns: smart components handle data loading, presentational components only render data
anti_patterns: Using @Input()/@Output() decorators instead of input()/output() functions
Using *ngIf/*ngFor instead of @if/@for control flow syntax
Injecting repositories directly instead of services in components
Putting business logic in components instead of service layer

faq.question: What Angular version is required for standalone components?
faq.answer: Angular 14+ supports standalone components, but input()/output() functions and control flow syntax require Angular 17.2+.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with Angular 17 or 18?
faq.answer: Yes, but some features like input()/output() functions require Angular 17.2+. Use decorator-based @Input/@Output for older versions.

faq.question: Does this skill work with nx monorepo projects?
faq.answer: Yes, the patterns are compatible with Nx monorepos. Adjust import paths for your workspace structure.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, this is a prompt-based skill with no code execution or network access. It only provides guidance.

faq.question: Why is my component not updating when data changes?
faq.answer: Ensure you use OnPush change detection and call signal.set() or signal.update() to trigger change detection properly.

faq.question: How does this differ from Angular CLI generation?
faq.answer: This skill applies modern Angular 20 patterns. Angular CLI generates legacy syntax by default that requires manual updates.
